column11: Review Text

A stop for lunch after a tour of Galle. Lovely stadium and lunch was delicious. Plenty of choice and eaten in a great setting overlooking the ground. A quick stop to the merchandise shop to get our  Grandsons a gift completed our day.

As part of my visit to Sri Lanka, it was a must to see the Galle Cricket ground. This was saved from ruin post the Tsunami by Shane Warne who organized a cricket game raising over $1m. Warnie is a legend here. There is a media box located at one end of the ground as well as the Players rooms. At square leg, you will find the Pavillion. Word has it that this is the place to be when watching a game. A beautiful stadium located next to the Fort, watch a game from there, with a quaint old-fashioned scoreboard. I can't wait to watch the next game there, Bangladesh soon, and see it on tv. A must see for any sporting enthusiast.

Go the the members.  Be polite and you'll get in and have a great time in one of the most novel and romantic cricket venues in the world, surely? Little known that after the tsunami Shane Warne and other international cricketers all put their hands in their pockets to help restore this ground.
This is the main stadium for cricket in galle. Cricket is an all time favourite sports for the sri langkans. The ground is packed during games.

We stay in Sri Lanka 6 months every year and the cricket club has become a firm favourite,  the last 2 weeks we have watched cricket and it was extremely enjoyable , great atmosphere and exceptional food , service and value for money. The food it's definitely worth trying , great taste and fairly priced , but be carful as portions are huge , call in if your passing during the day you will be made most welcome and definitely won't be disappointed

3rd day of the 2nd test against Australia which the Sri Lankans won. The ground is very undeveloped as a stadium and I hope it continues that way for many years and when they do develop it they leave at least a 3rd open. Spent the day in the Cricket club and it was very good with cold drinks and good food and a great view from side on.

Spent a half day watching a provincial cricket match, Galle v Colombo. For only 200 rupees (Â£0.65) become a member, with access to the bar & restaurant and a great view of the cricket. A must for all cricket fans to be at one the famous ground in the world.
Obviously one of the most beautiful sports grounds anywhere in the world, appropriately situated at the end of Wackwella Rd
A cricket field like many other. Only extra is that it is near the historical walls. Not worth the visit itseld but almost all see it when going to Galle fort.

column8: The best ground in the Island for test cricket
column11: Cricket is very famous in Sri Lanka and there are many cricket grounds all around the country. But if you love classic cricket, that is, of course, the "TEST MATCHES" this is the best ground in the country without a doubt. Surrounded by the historical and colossal Galle fort and crowded Galle city, this ground gives you the best of cricket. Many dining places, hotels and B&Bs are located nearby. Bus and train stations are 100 m away. Gound was damaged by the Tsunami in 2004 and rebuilt. There are open grass banks, shaded seating areas as well as ACed boxes for the crowd to enjoy the play.  Well, toilets aren't the best but manageable I guess.

This is the famous cricket ground in Galle where I believe international test matches are played. From Galle fort, walk up to the clock tower - you'll get great views of the cricket ground and the pitch.

A great Cricket Ground which I've watched over the years. We watched for a few  overs from the Fort viewpoint as a first class game was underway. Reminded me of the old SCG days !! The ground was badly damaged during the Tsunami and Aussie great Shane Warne (with little fanfare) paid for the restoration of the ground ! A great gesture to the locals who wanted to rename the Stadium but Warney declined !

We were walking around Galle mid morning and it was getting very hot when we noticed ther was a cricket match on.  We paid 100 rupees each and we were in the Members area watching the crcket in the shade and relative cool.  We watched a First Class match and drank beer and had lunch at the Galle Cricket Club Restaurant which was very enjoyable.  A fabulous few hours were spent here.
The stadium looks really nice from the fort. It was a great feeling to observe cricket being played at the stadium. The setting is just marvelous.

With the Indian Ocean the proverbial stone's throw away, the location of the pitch is surely one of the most compelling. It was started as a race track in 1876, only permanently becoming a cricket pitch in 1927. It was extensively damaged in the 2004 tsunami, acting as a point of refuge due to its size. International matches are played here. The view of the stadium from Galle Fort is beautiful.

I didn't enter the stadium but watched the scenic view from the galle fort. Wow simply awesome stadium touching distance from the sea. It should be one of the scenic stadiums in the world where there is a high possibility that the ball one day will be hit into the sea.

Located in front of the Galle Fort and surrounded by the Indian ocean on two sides, this stadium has had a recent introduction to international cricket with the first match played in 1998. It was devastated by the 2004 tsunami and was not again used until December 2007. Shane Warne and Ian Botham are revered here for their major contributions towards the cost of renovations. Picturesque location.
The ground is very scenic and so close to the sea. We happened to see some live action on the day that we visited.

Wonderdful to visit Galle and there to be a match on A school game featuring St Alysious College Ground staff very friendy and told me a lot about the history, and Sri Lanka team I was asked the obvious question "Would I be back in March 2020 for 2nd Test v England with the Army Barmy" Great place to see cricket All cricket lovers shoud go

Was in Galle during the NZ v Sri Lanka test so we came and watched 2 days play. 4000Rs to sit in an aircon box was good value. Only bad thing was no food or drink were available in the box. Truly picturesque ground for a great game.

Galle International Stadium is one of the famous cricket staudium in Sri Lanka. It is situated near by Galle Fort and we had nice view of the stadium from the top of the fort and nearby Indian ocean is there. We enjoyed few minutes Test match between Sri Lanka and New Zealand.
Just went there on a whim while visiting Dutch fort, a university match was going on, had a beer and watched the match for a bit. Beautiful cricket ground and with an amazing background
There was no game on whilst we were there, the world cup was on in England but nice to see, well maintained and you can imagine what it would be like with a match on this cricket obsessed country

One of the most beautiful stadiums in the world. What a location. Really nice to explore the fort and be able to look into and over the ground from multiple aspects. Can't wait to come back and watch when a game is actually on.
This is a large stadium just outside the fort ramparts. In fact you can see into the stadium from the walls. We enjoyed watching a game of cricket from there.

We walked around the perimeter as there was a match going on at the time. The ground is very small I was told it will only hold 15 000 spectators but a lot of the locals watch for free from the walls of the close by fort. We were told that one of the main pavilions was rebuilt after tsunami from money given by Shane Warne not sure if this is true or not.
Although we didn't enter the grounds we wandered around the perimeter and gained good views from the nearby fort. Worth a visit just to say you've been there.

My wife and I visited here during our recent tour of Sri Lanka ðŸ‡±ðŸ‡°. We didnâ€™t enter the ground as there was a youth team match on so we made do with exploring the out side. The authorities have done a superb job of restoring the Stadium after the 2004 Tsunami. The before and after pictures show just how much work was required. Itâ€™s now back to its glorious selfðŸ˜‚. The best views are to be obtained from the walls of the Dutch Fort opposite. High Recommended
This Galle cricket ground is one of the world famous cricket ground that place more world records and players that made the cricket history changed.

We went in March 2019 after the ground had closed for test matches, so I'm not reviewing a test match! There are fantastic views of the ground from Galle Fort (free to walk around) and from the circular road that encircles the stadium. We went to the front enterance and a guard let us in to take a few extra photos and also took a photo of us. If you're a cricket fan in Galle looking to seek out some history, then do still head here as you can get into the ground and have a wee look around.
my brother and myself watched England at this test and enjoyed the experience very friendly staff they could not no enough to help

Probably the most low-key international stadium Iâ€™ve ever visited. Thereâ€™s a fairly uninspiring pavilion and a grandstand (if you can call it that) and the rest is open. To be fair, there was a school game on when we were there and we were allowed in to watch for free. Well located opposite the bus and train stations. Nice view of the fort behind one end.

Ocean both the side of the stadium, nice pavilion end facing road and fort behind the fort end, the view of the fort and the clock tower from the pavilion side was awesome. Watched many test and ODI matches live in television but my first view of the Galle stadium in my necked eyes was totally different and its beautiful. Specially the view of the stadium from the fort is magical.
This Stadium functions under the management of Galle Cricket Club. It is a small ground if compared to other Cricket Stadiums in SL, but hosts some intl matches.

This was my 3rd test match at the wonderful Galle venue and it may have been my last, as there are rumours it is to be demolished. Without knowing the full details, it appears that UNSESCO have complained about a recently built stand spoiling the view of the fort. Yes it has its faults (uneven walkways, debris lying around) but there are few better venues to watch cricket.

We thoroughly enjoyed the experience of watching Test cricket at this lovely little ground. There was a great atmosphere and we were fortunate that the weather was perfect for the duration of the match. The ground only holds around 8000 people but there was probably another 2000 people watching for free from the ramparts. The downside is that we watched possibly the last Test match that will be played at that ground. The authorities want to build a larger and more modern ground elsewhere....what a shame.
Amazing cricket stadium located on the sea dhire and just outside galle fort. The view from galle fort is great for this stadium
Definately one of the most picturesque locations for a stadium, surrounded by the fort and the sea. Unfortunately scarred by the new pavillion that has been built.
Loved the day watching the cricket, it is a lovely stadium, very unique. Great setting right by the fort.
Great location for a test match, with easy access to the fort at lunchtime for the variety of bars and restaurants to try the wonderful local seafood

It may not be the greatest test ground in the world but itâ€™s got one of the best overlooked sites. A world heritage fort is yards away and may be one of the best free seats to watch the match, free entrance into the fort is amazing as itâ€™s contains a mini village of bars shops and eateries. A nice break between sessions. Prices were cheap and food and people were superb....
Iconic cricket stadium of Galle located outside galle fort and in sea shore.  You can have the best view from the galle fort

Two days was not enough in this beautiful cricket ground. it had a great atmosphere - OK it was generated by the English supporters but news of this ground possibly being closed is a travesty - we heard conflicting accounts of its future but I'm sure sense will prevail. The backdrop of the Fort is comparable only to Newlands at Cape Town./

300SLR to watch Eng v Sri Lanka from the grass bank. Loved it! Slightly rickety in parts, no loud speaker so no announcements, portaloos were interesting! And had it rained we may have been in trouble. But it was a wonderful few days of cricket and I loved the whole experience from start to finish.

This iconic cricket ground is one of the must visit test match venues in the world. Try to visit when England are playing Sri Lanka; you will be assured of seeing cricket played in front of a large passionate crowd. The Galle Fort ramparts make a majestic backdrop to the stadium.

There's nothing like watching a test match from the Fort Ramparts. I do hope they don't follow through on the plans to relocate this ground, it would be a travesty and do a lot of harm to tourism in Galle

Got to be one the top grounds in world cricket for location, easy access, option to go up onto the fort ramparts and watch for a change if you choose. Great atmosphere, no shortage of food and drink options, and a resounding England win! Lovely.

The last time I was here was 2007 and in was I believe the first match played there after the Tsunami. Wonderful ground surrounded with beach, Galle fort and Galle city. Galle cricket ground destroyed in 2004 by Tsunami. The stadium is right in the heart of the city, you get an excellent view of this stadium from the nearby fort. The view from outside is fantastic and more so when you go inside. Itâ€™s not a very big stadium, but it is beautiful. Galle International Stadium is cornered on two sides by the ocean â€“ and overseen by a 16th century Dutch fort, with some great vantage points over looking the fort and the cricket ground. Really amazing it has to rank as one of the most picturesque stadiums of the world. But this time England competed a thumping 211 run victory on day four and ending their 13-match winless streak away from home. Now we head for Kandy and another new ground in Pallekele cricket stadium.

Our son was lucky enough to play a school match against a Sri Lankan team at this amazing ground, usually the home of international matches. What a fantastic location, looking across to the fort, The staff were lovely, letting us park inside the grounds, showing us around and telling us stories about when the tsunami had filled the region with water destroying many of the facilities. And some great cricket was played and enjoyed!  A fantastic experience for all.
Nice view in front of the fort area. Many  international cricket matches are played here. Visited once

The cricket ground is a convenient few minutes' walk from the train station & in full view from the ramparts of the old town fortress.  Sadly there was no match on when we visited but we enjoyed sitting atop the steep fortification & imaging the sound of willow on leather.... Next time!
I this this is one of most attractive international cricket ground in the world. Gall Fort , Gall Beach all around is very nice. Quick access via Train , Bus , Express way

This stadium is right in the heart of the city and even if you are in a bus you can watch the action going on inside. You get an excellent view of this stadium from the nearby fort. The railway station is also a few minutes walk from the stadium. The view from outside is fantastic and more so when you go inside. Its not a very big stadium, but it is beautiful. The turf is lush and well manicured. The stadium houses the Galle Cricket Club. Being a cricket fan, coming from a cricket adoring nation and having watched many matches being played here on TV, it was nostalgic to be right there, even though there was no match being played. They had to redo the entire stadium after the Tsunami, but it now looks as if nothing had taken place. The best part is that standing on the road outside you are on eye level contact with the pitch. Really amazing it has to rank as one of the most picturesque stadiums of the world

till last South Africa tour (2018) Sri Lanka cricket team won 18 matches out of 31 matches in Galle cricket stadium. Wonderful ground surrounded with beach, Galle fort and Galle city. Galle cricket ground and stadium destroyed in 2004 by Tsunami.

The Galle international cricket stadium was a pleasant surprise to see as it is right opposite the main entrance to Galle Fort. I've seen cricket games from here on TV so it was an unexpected bonus to get a chance to pay a quick visit and have a look even though there was no game on. Great views of it from Galle Fort Ramparts.

Galle International stadium is situated near the Galle fort and covered both sides by the Indian Ocean. If you are a cricket fan you should visit on your way. You have a railway station next to it, and one side the fort and the other the ocean.. cannot get better than this. There are plenty of historical cricket matches that have been played in this very venue. Could not venture much since it was raining bad and the only shot I got was from the vehicle with a hazy wet window :( but certainly worth a visit
A great place for cricket fans. is difficult to get access to the ground if there is no game on. A spectacular view of it from the top of the Forts.

right next to railway station and flanked by the fort, this is most casual international cricket stadium you can hope to see. u can literally stand next to boundary rope and have a clear view of the pitch. the ground is compact. a must visit if you are a cricket enthusiast, we tried to get into the ground itself but were denied permission. if you are in kandy you can spend good 30/40 minutes walking around the stadium
Happened to be in Galle when the Nat school finals were on, U19's. Best game of live cricket I've ever seen, well worth going if you are a fan of sport. The crowd and atmosphere was immense.

Managed to tag on to a visit from some Somerset CC members organised by Sporta. Thanks Mark! It was interesting to see the view from the wicket and the dressing rooms.  Probably more for a cricket enthusiast.
